qas.question: Who was the founder of the Roman Republic?
What were stand-ins for child sacrifices to Mania?
Who was Mania in Roman religion?
What leader was the first consul of the Roman Republic?
What acts were sometimes arranged so as to be sacrifices?

context: The small <a1_0>woolen dolls<a1_0/> called Maniae, hung on the Compitalia shrines, were thought a symbolic replacement for child-sacrifice to Mania, as <a2_0>Mother of the Lares<a2_0/>. The Junii took credit for its abolition by their ancestor <a0_0><a3_0>L. Junius Brutus<a3_0/><a0_0/>, traditionally Rome's Republican founder and first consul. Political or military <a4_0>executions<a4_0/> were sometimes conducted in such a way that they evoked human sacrifice, whether deliberately or in the perception of witnesses; Marcus Marius Gratidianus was a gruesome example.
